answers_list:
[reasoning process] To compute \(\cos 60^\circ\), we can utilize our knowledge of the unit circle or the properties of a special triangle. The angle \(60^\circ\) is a common angle in trigonometry, corresponding to \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) radians. In a 30-60-90 triangle, the ratios of the lengths of the sides are well-known: the side opposite the \(30^\circ\) angle is \(1\), the side opposite the \(60^\circ\) angle is \(\sqrt{3}\), and the hypotenuse is \(2\). 

Using this relationship, we find that \(\cos 60^\circ\) corresponds to the ratio of the adjacent side (to the \(60^\circ\) angle) to the hypotenuse. The adjacent side (which is the side opposite the \(30^\circ\) angle) has a length of \(1\) and the hypotenuse has a length of \(2\). Thus, we have:

\[
\cos 60^\circ = \frac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{1}{2}
\]

[Verification] We can verify this using the unit circle approach. On the unit circle, the angle \(60^\circ\) corresponds to the point at \((\frac{1}{2}, \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2})\). The x-coordinate of this point is the value of \(\cos 60^\circ\), which again confirms our earlier finding:

\[
\cos 60^\circ = \frac{1}{2}
\]

Consequently, both methods provide the same result, affirming the correctness of our computation.

[Final Answer] The answer is \\boxed{\frac{1}{2}} \n#### \frac{1}{2}
